original_title: US funds Sri Lanka battery swapping station for e-bikes
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) said it will fund two battery swapping stations for electric bikes in Sri Lanka.
Sling Mobility (Pvt) Ltd will get a grant to build the two stations from USAIDs Sri Lanka Energy Program which also supports EV charging stations.
Battery swapping or switching stations allow electric vehicle owners to get a re-charge by changing the battery instead of waiting for the vehicle to be charged.
Under the project 20 riders will be recruited to pilot e-bikes for delivery services.
Love Yadav, general partner for Sling Mobility said the firm wanted to improve EV affordability and faster adoption, reducing rider downtime, and building a platform for sustainable charging.
“The United States and the American people are proud of our enduring and robust 75-year partnership with the people of Sri Lanka,” said USAID Mission Director Gabriel Grau.

“We remain fully committed to support locally led initiatives to advance E-technologies that are critical to promote the progress of a nation in an environmentally friendly and cost-effective way,” USAID Mission Director Gabriel Grau said in a statement.
“Sling Mobility is a technology solutions company focused on electric vehicles, and its demand driven approach is key to future of EVs in Sri Lanka and beyond,” said
The results of the pilot program will show the energy project and Sling Mobility the feasibility of promoting E-battery swapping stations in the country, USAID said. (Colombo/Apr22/2023)
